title: $F$-pure threshold for the symmetric determinantal ring

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We give a value for the $F$-pure threshold at the maximal homogeneous ideal $\mathfrak{m}$ of the symmetric determinantal ring over a field of prime characteristic. The answer is characteristic independent, so we immediately get the log canonical threshold in characteristic zero as well.

## 1. InTRODUCTION

The $F$-pure threshold, introduced by Takagi and Watanabe in [TW04], is a numerical invariant associated to rings with $F$-pure singularities. $F$-pure singularities are an example class of $F$-singularities, which are classes of singularities defined in positive characteristic using the Frobenius map. Suppose $R$ is a reduced $F$-finite $F$-pure ring of characteristic $p>0$, and let $\mathfrak{a} \subseteq R$ be a nonzero ideal. For a real number $t \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$, the pair $\left(R, \mathfrak{a}^{t}\right)$ is called $F$-pure if for every $q=p^{e} \gg 0$, there exists an element $f \in \mathfrak{a}^{\lceil(q-1) t\rfloor}$ (where $\lfloor(q-1) t\rfloor$ is the greatest integer less than or equal to the real number $(q-1) t$ ) such that the map $R \rightarrow R^{1 / q}$ which sends 1 to $f^{1 / q}$ splits as an $R$-module homomorphism. The $F$-pure threshold of $\mathfrak{a}$ is defined to be

$$
\operatorname{fpt}(\mathfrak{a}):=\sup \left\{t \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \mid\left(R, \mathfrak{a}^{t}\right) \text { is } F \text {-pure }\right\}
$$

When $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{m}$ is the maximal homogeneous ideal of $R$, we will simply refer to $\operatorname{fpt}(\mathfrak{m})$ as the $F$-pure threshold of $R$.

The $F$-pure threshold has been calculated for the determinantal rings of generic matrices [STV17, Proposition 4.3], Hankel matrices [CMSV18, Theorem 4.5], and is trivial for skew-symmetric matrices (see section 2.1 for an explanation). However, to the author's knowledge, $\operatorname{fpt}(\mathfrak{m})$ has been unknown for the symmetric matrix case. We provide an answer in Theorem 2.6, as well as a proof that the symmetric determinantal ring is $F$-pure, a fact not clearly stated in the literature.

Note. At the time of writing this article, the author was notified of the recent paper [CSV24], which includes a proof of the more general property of $F$-regularity for symmetric determinantal rings, and mentions the same conclusion of Proposition 2.5 in this article. Our work is independent of that paper.

# 2. Symmetric Determinantial Rings 

Suppose that $X=\left(x_{i j}\right)$ is a symmetric $n \times n$ generic matrix (i.e., $x_{i j}=x_{j i}$ ), let $\mathbb{k}[X]=\mathbb{k}\left[x_{i j} \mid 1 \leq i \leq j \leq n\right]$ be the polynomial ring over a field $\mathbb{k}$ with the entries of $X$ as its variables, and $I_{t}(X)$ be the ideal generated by the $t$-minors of $X$. For an integer $1 \leq t \leq n$ let $R=\mathbb{k}[X] / I_{t}(X)$ be the symmetric determinantal ring. A formula for the $a$-invariant of $R$ has been given by Barile in [Bar94]. When $R$ is given the standard grading this is given as follows:

$$
a(R)= \begin{cases}-(t-1) \frac{n}{2}, & \text { if } n \equiv t(\bmod 2) \\ -(t-1) \frac{n+1}{2}, & \text { if } n \not \equiv t(\bmod 2)\end{cases}
$$

In [Con94] it is shown that the graded canonical module of $R$ is

$$
\omega_{R}= \begin{cases}R\left(-(t-1) \frac{n}{2}\right), & \text { if } n \equiv t(\bmod 2) \\ \mathfrak{p}\left(-(t-1) \frac{n-1}{2}\right), & \text { if } n \not \equiv t(\bmod 2)\end{cases}
$$

where $\mathfrak{p}$ is the prime ideal generated by the $t-1$ minors of the first $t-1$ rows of $X$. In [Got79] and [Got77] Goto shows that $R$ is Gorenstein if and only if $n \equiv t(\bmod 2)$, and the divisor class group of $R$ is $\mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z}$ generated by $[\mathfrak{p}]$.
Lemma 2.1. [DSMnNnB23, (4.2)] Suppose $S$ is a polynomial ring over a field of characteristic $p>0$, and let $I \subset S$ be a prime ideal of $h=\operatorname{height}(I)$. Then $I^{(h(p-1))} \subseteq$ $\left(I^{[p]}:_{S} I\right)$, i.e., $I^{(h(p-1))+1} \subseteq I^{[p]}$.
Proof. To show the containment $I^{(h(p-1))+1} \subseteq I^{[p]}$, it is enough to show it locally at all the associated primes of $S / I^{[p]}$. However, since the Frobenius map is flat, the set of associated primes of $S / I^{[p]}$ is the same as for $S / I$, which consists only of $I$ since it is prime. In the regular local ring $\left(S_{I}, I S_{I}\right)$ the symbolic power of $I S_{I}$ coincides with its ordinary power since $I S_{I}$ is a maximal ideal. Hence it follows that

$$
\left(I S_{I}\right)^{(h(p-1))} I=\left(I S_{I}\right)^{h(p-1)} I=\left(I S_{I}\right)^{h(p-1)+1}
$$

Since $\left(S_{I}, I S_{I}\right)$ has dimension $h=\operatorname{height}(I)$, its unique maximal ideal $I S_{I}$ is generated by $h$ elements $g_{1}, \ldots, g_{h}$. The power $\left(I S_{I}\right)^{h(p-1)+1}$ is generated by $g_{1}^{a_{1}} \cdots g_{h}^{a_{h}}$ such that $a_{1}+\cdots+a_{h}=h(p-1)+1$. By the pigeonhole principle, at least one $a_{i} \geq p$, hence it follows that $\left(I S_{I}\right)^{h(p-1)+1} \subseteq I^{[p]} S_{I}$.
Proposition 2.2. Over a field of characteristic $p>0$ the symmetric determinantal ring $R$ is $F$-pure.
Proof. Let $I_{t}=I_{t}(X)$, and $S=\mathbb{k}[X]$ be the polynomial ring in $n(n+1) / 2$ many variables. We will apply Fedder's criterion: $R$ is $F$-pure if and only if $\left(I_{t}^{[p]}:_{S} I_{t}\right) \nsubseteq \mathfrak{m}_{S}^{[p]}$, where $\mathfrak{m}_{S}=\left(x_{i j}\right)$ is the maximal homogeneous ideal of $S$. Thus, in order to show that $R$ is $F$-pure, we need to find an element $f \in\left(I_{t}^{[p]}:_{S} I_{t}\right) \backslash \mathfrak{m}_{S}^{[p]}$.

Let $\mathfrak{D}=d_{1} \cdots d_{n}$ be a product of $i$-minors $d_{i}$ of the $i \times i$ submatrices in the bottomleft corner of $X$ (for $i=1, \ldots, n$ ), whose diagonals are the $n$ distinct diagonals of $X$ (see Example 2.3 below). Our proposed element will be $f=\mathfrak{D}^{p-1}$. The leading term of $\mathfrak{D}$ with respect to the diagonal term ordering

$$
x_{11}>x_{12}>\cdots>x_{1 n}>x_{21}>\cdots>x_{n-1 n}>x_{n n}
$$

is in $(\mathfrak{D})=\prod_{1 \leq i \leq j \leq n} x_{i j}$, which is the product of all the distinct variables of $X$, hence it is a squarefree monomial. This implies $\mathfrak{D}^{p-1} \notin \mathfrak{m}_{S}^{[p]}$.

Next, we need to show $\mathfrak{D}^{p-1} I_{t} \subseteq I_{t}^{[p]}$, i.e., $\mathfrak{D}^{p-1} \in\left(I_{t}^{[p]}:_{S} I_{t}\right)$. It suffices to prove this containment after localizing at the prime ideal $I_{t}$. If one can show that $\mathfrak{D}$ belongs to the symbolic power $I_{t}^{(h)}$, where $h=\operatorname{height}\left(I_{t}\right)$, then it would follow

$$
\mathfrak{D}^{p-1} I_{t} S_{I_{t}} \subseteq\left(\left(I_{t} S_{I_{t}}\right)^{(h)}\right)^{p-1} I_{t} S_{I_{t}}=\left(I_{t} S_{I_{t}}\right)^{h(p-1)+1} \subseteq I_{t}^{[p]} S_{I_{t}}
$$

where $\left(I_{t} S_{I_{t}}\right)^{(h)}=\left(I_{t} S_{I_{t}}\right)^{h}$, because $I_{t} S_{I_{t}}$ is the (unique) maximal ideal of $S_{I_{t}}$, and the last containment follows from Lemma 2.1. We will now show $\mathfrak{D} \in I_{t}^{(h)}$. In [Kut74, Theorem 1], Kutz has shown that $\operatorname{dim} R=n(t-1)-\frac{1}{2}(t-1)(t-2)$, hence it follows

$$
h=\operatorname{dim} S-\operatorname{dim} R=\frac{n(n+1)}{2}-n(t-1)+\frac{(t-1)(t-2)}{2}
$$

In general, suppose $\Delta$ is a product $\delta_{1} \cdots \delta_{u}$ of $a_{i}$-minors $\delta_{i}$ of $X$, where the vector $\left(a_{1}, \ldots, a_{u}\right) \in \mathbb{N}^{u}$ is called the shape of $\Delta$. With the previous notation, the symbolic power $I_{t}^{(k)}$ is described by

$$
\left[\Delta \in I_{t}^{(k)}\right] \Longleftrightarrow\left[a_{i} \leq n \forall i \text { and } \gamma_{t}(\Delta):=\sum_{i=1}^{u} \max \left\{0, a_{i}-t+1\right\} \geq k\right]
$$

(see [JMnV15, Proposition 4.3].) We must show $\gamma_{t}(\mathfrak{D}) \geq h$. Observe that the product $\mathfrak{D}=d_{1} d_{2} \cdots d_{n}$ has shape $(1,2, \ldots, n)$, and note that $i-t+1>0 \Leftrightarrow i>t-1$, hence $\max \{0, i-t+1\}=i-t+1$ for $t \leq i \leq n$. Thus, one has

$$
\begin{aligned}
\gamma_{t}(\mathfrak{D}) & =\sum_{i=t}^{n}(i-t+1) \\
& =\sum_{i=t}^{n} i+\sum_{i=t}^{n}(1-t) \\
& =\frac{n(n+1)}{2}-\frac{t(t-1)}{2}+(n-t+1)(1-t) \\
& =\frac{n(n+1)}{2}-n(t-1)+\frac{(t-1)(t-2)}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

i.e., $\gamma_{t}(\mathfrak{D})=$ height $\left(I_{t}\right)=h$, so it follows that $\mathfrak{D} \in I_{t}^{(h)}$.

Example 2.3. For the $3 \times 3$ symmetric matrix

$$
X=\left(\begin{array}{lll}
x_{11} & x_{12} & x_{13} \\
x_{12} & x_{22} & x_{23} \\
x_{13} & x_{23} & x_{33}
\end{array}\right)
$$

the $i$-minors $d_{i}(i=1,2,3)$ of the $i \times i$ botom-left corner of $X$ are

$$
d_{1}=x_{13}, \quad d_{2}=\left|\begin{array}{ll}
x_{12} & x_{22} \\
x_{13} & x_{23}
\end{array}\right|, \quad d_{3}=|X|
$$

which have leading terms in $\left(d_{1}\right)=x_{13}, \operatorname{in}\left(d_{2}\right)=x_{12} x_{23}$, and in $\left(d_{3}\right)=x_{11} x_{22} x_{33}$, hence $\mathfrak{D}=d_{1} d_{2} d_{3}$ has squarefree leading term $x_{11} x_{12} x_{13} x_{22} x_{23} x_{33}$.

Lemma 2.4. [Gri, Lemma 1.71] Let $Q$ be a primary ideal of a Noetherian ring $R$. If $P$ is a prime ideal that contains $Q$, then $Q R_{P} \cap R=Q$.

Proposition 2.5. Over a field $\mathbb{k}$ of arbitrary characteristic, let $\mathfrak{p}$ be the prime ideal of $R=\mathbb{k}[X] / I_{t}(X)$ generated by the $t-1$ minors of the first $t-1$ rows of $X$. Then the second symbolic power $\mathfrak{p}^{(2)}$ is principally generated by the $(t-1)$-minor in the top left-hand corner of $X$.

Proof. Let $d$ represent the $(t-1)$-minor in the top left corner of $X$. By Proposition (1) of [Got77] the radical of the principal ideal $(d)=d R$ is the prime ideal $\mathfrak{p}$. To see that $(d)$ is primary note that $R$ is a Cohen-Macaulay domain by [Kut74, Theorem 1], and $d \in R$ is a nonzero divisor, hence $R /(d)$ is Cohen-Macaulay, so all associated primes of $(d)$ are minimal. Since $\sqrt{(d)}=\mathfrak{p}$ is prime, it follows that $(d)$ is $\mathfrak{p}$-primary.

By Proposition (2) of [Got77], the local ring $R_{\mathfrak{p}}$ is a discrete valuation ring with valuation $v_{\mathfrak{p}}$, and $v_{\mathfrak{p}}(d)=2$. Let $(d) R_{\mathfrak{p}}$ be the extension of $(d)$ in $R$ to $R_{\mathfrak{p}}$. This is a nonzero proper ideal in $R_{\mathfrak{p}}$ by the valuation of $d$. Since every proper nontrivial ideal of a DVR $R_{\mathfrak{p}}$ is a power of the unique maximal ideal $\mathfrak{p} R_{\mathfrak{p}}$, we have $(d) R_{\mathfrak{p}}=\mathfrak{p}^{m} R_{\mathfrak{p}}=\{a \in$ $\left.R_{\mathfrak{p}} \mid v_{\mathfrak{p}}(a) \geq m\right\}$ for some $m \in \mathbb{N}$. From $v_{\mathfrak{p}}(d)=2$, it follows that $(d) R_{\mathfrak{p}} \subseteq \mathfrak{p}^{2} R_{\mathfrak{p}}$. Also, $d \in \mathfrak{p}^{m} R_{\mathfrak{p}}$ implies $2=v_{\mathfrak{p}}(d) \geq m$, so $m$ is either 1 or 2 . However, $\mathfrak{p}^{m} R_{\mathfrak{p}} \subseteq \mathfrak{p}^{2} R_{\mathfrak{p}}$ can only mean $m=2$, so it follows $(d) R_{\mathfrak{p}}=\mathfrak{p}^{2} R_{\mathfrak{p}}$.

Since $d \in \mathfrak{p}$, one has $(d) \subseteq \mathfrak{p}$, and it follows from Lemma 2.4 and our previous discussion that $(d)=(d) R_{\mathfrak{p}} \cap R=\mathfrak{p}^{2} R_{\mathfrak{p}} \cap R=\mathfrak{p}^{(2)}$.

Theorem 2.6. The F-pure threshold of the symmetric determinantial ring $R=\mathbb{k}[X] / I_{t}(X)$ over an $F$-finite field $\mathbb{k}$ is

$$
\operatorname{fpt}(\mathfrak{m})=\frac{n(t-1)}{2}
$$

When $\mathbb{k}$ has characteristic zero, the log canonical threshold of $\mathfrak{m}$ shares the same value.
Proof. The ring $R=\mathbb{k}[X] / I_{t}$ is Gorenstein if and only if $n \equiv t(\bmod 2)$, hence it follows from [DSNnB18, Theorem 5.2] and equation (2.1) that $\operatorname{fpt}(\mathfrak{m})=-a(R)=(t-1) \frac{n}{2}$, when $n \equiv t(\bmod 2)$. Now, suppose $R$ is non-Gorenstein, i.e., $n \not \equiv t(\bmod 2)$. Its $a$-invariant and graded canonical module are respectively $a(R)=-(t-1) \frac{n+1}{2}$ and $\omega_{R}=\mathfrak{p}\left(-(t-1) \frac{n-1}{2}\right)$ (see (2.2)). Since the class group $\mathrm{Cl}(R)$ is cyclic of order 2, the ring $R$ is $\mathbb{Q}$-Gorenstein, so we will apply [STV17, Proposition 4.5]. We determine the generating degree $D$ of $\omega_{R}^{(2)}$. First, note that $\mathfrak{p}^{(2)}$ is principally generated by a $(t-1)$ minor, by Proposition 2.5, hence as graded modules $\mathfrak{p}^{(2)} \cong R(-(t-1))$. The second

symbolic power of $\omega_{R}$ is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{R}^{(2)}=\left(\mathfrak{p}\left(\frac{-(t-1)(n-1)}{2}\right)\right)^{(2)} & =\mathfrak{p}^{(2)}\left(2 \cdot \frac{-(t-1)(n-1)}{2}\right) \\
& =R(-(t-1))(-(t-1)(n-1)) \\
& =R(-(t-1)-(t-1)(n-1)) \\
& =R(-(t-1) n)
\end{aligned}
$$

which is generated in degree $D=(t-1) n$. It follows that $\operatorname{fpt}(\mathfrak{m})=D / c=n(t-1) / 2$.
In characteristic zero, one has by [MTW05, Theorem 3.4] that the log canonical threshold of $R$ is

$$
\operatorname{lct}(\mathfrak{m})=\lim _{p \rightarrow \infty} \operatorname{fpt}\left(\mathfrak{m}_{R_{p}}\right)=\frac{n(t-1)}{2}
$$

where $\mathfrak{m}_{R_{p}}$ is the image of $\mathfrak{m}$ in $R_{p}$, the prime reduction modulo $p$ of $R$.
2.1. Ring of Pfaffians. Let $X=\left(x_{i j}\right)$ be an $n \times n$ skew-symmetric matrix (i.e., $x_{i i}=0, x_{i j}=-x_{j i}$ for $i<j), \mathbb{k}[X]$ be the polynomial ring in the entries of $X$, and $\operatorname{Pf}_{2 t}(X)$ be the ideal generated by the $2 t$-Pfaffians of $X$. The ring of Pfaffians $R=$ $\mathbb{k}[X] / \operatorname{Pf}_{2 t}(X)$ is Gorenstein [Avr79] and strongly $F$-regular [Bata01]. Its $a$-invariant has been computed in [BH92, Corollary 1.7], and assuming it is standard graded, is given by $a(R)=-n(t-1)$, if $2 t \leq n$. By [DSNnB18, Theorem 5.2] we immediately get the following.

Proposition 2.7. When $2 t \leq n$ and $\mathbb{k}$ is an $F$-finite field, the $F$-pure threshold of the ring of Pfaffians $R=\mathbb{k}[X] / \operatorname{Pf}_{2 t}(X)$ is $\operatorname{fpt}(\mathfrak{m})=n(t-1)$.
